content: The "Notch Fairness Act of 1998" establishes a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for those eligible during a transitional period. The "Notch Fairness Act of 1998" amends Section 215(a) of the Social Security Act to include a transitional increase amount for individuals described in paragraph (4)(B). This increase is added to the individual's primary insurance amount as computed under paragraph (1). The Notch Fairness Act of 1998 introduces a transitional increase amount for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits, calculated by multiplying the excess under former law by the applicable percentage determined by a specific table. The Notch Fairness Act of 1998 introduces a transitional increase amount for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits, with applicable percentages ranging from 55 percent in 1979 to 3 percent in 1987. Any election filed after December 31, 1998, will be null and void. Upon receipt of a timely election, the Commissioner certifies it to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment. The Notch Fairness Act of 1998 allows for a $5,000 total payment in 4 annual installments from the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to eligible individuals. A timely election must be filed with the Commissioner of Social Security by December 31, 1998, for the payment to be processed by the Treasury. The Notch Fairness Act of 1998 certifies receipt of timely elections for a $5,000 total payment in 4 annual installments from the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury will make the first payment by July 1, 1999, and for benefit calculation purposes, certain provisions will not apply. The amendments made by the Notch Fairness Act of 1998 will be effective as if they were included in the Social Security Amendments of 1977. No increase in benefits will be applied before July 1999, and the changes will only affect benefits payable after fiscal year 2002.
